derivation.yuyuan_name: mid 16th cent.: from late Latin transpositio(n-) (see trans-, position)

entry.def: If you transpose something from one place or situation to another, you move it there.

example.ex: Genetic engineers transpose or exchange bits of hereditary material from one organism to the next...
example.tran: 遗传工程师将某一生物的小段遗传物质调换到另一生物，或与其互换。

example.ex: The director transposes the action from 16th Century France to post-Civil War America.
example.tran: 导演把情节从 16 世纪的法国调换到内战后的美国。

entry.def: If you transpose two things, you reverse them or put them in each other's place.

example.ex: Many people inadvertently transpose digits of the ZIP code.
example.tran: 很多人疏忽之下会颠倒邮政编码中数字的顺序。

example.ex: …a short story in which he transposes the roles of poets and screenwriters.
example.tran: 他将诗人与编剧作了角色换位的短篇小说

entry.def: If you transpose a piece of music, you perform it or write it in a musical key which is different from the original one.

example.ex: She could play any piece of music she heard and transpose it into any key.
example.tran: 她能把听过的任何乐曲变以任何调演奏出来。

means.word_mean: 1. any abnormal position of the organs of the body
2. an event in which one thing is substituted for another;

sentences.sentence: "the replacement of lost blood by a transfusion of donor blood"

means.word_mean: 3. (genetics) a kind of mutation in which a chromosomal segment is transfered to a new position on the same or another chromosome
4. (mathematics) the transfer of a quantity form one side of an equation to the other along with a change of sign
5. (electricity) a rearrangement of the relative positions of power lines in order to minimize the effects of mutual capacitance and inductance;

sentences.sentence: "he wrote a textbook on the electrical effects of transposition"

means.word_mean: 6. the act of reversing the order or place of
7. (music) playing in a different key from the key intended; moving the pitch of a piece of music upwards or downwards
